awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Digital Farming Technologies, Traditional Knowledge, and Agrarian Livelihoods
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

Population shifts and shrinking agricultural land are increasing pressure on agricultural production, leading to food insecurity and economic, social and political instability in many regions. A range of private and public institutions aim to increase efficiency (more food from less land) by integrating digital farming technologies that provide farmers with algorithm-generated recommendations to predict and manage their farming (soil, plants, inputs, timing), finances (budgeting, credit) and insurance. They also seek to revive and incorporate farmers’ traditional knowledge and practices into the digital applications to promote agricultural innovation in food and enhance socio-economic welfare. This research project investigates the everyday experiences of the farmers with digital farming technologies and the impacts of these technologies on their farming knowledges, practices and income. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, the findings of this research will be disseminated to governmental and non-governmental organizations with the aim of improving social, economic, and ecological conditions of farmers and democratizing access to digital platforms and data in food systems. 

This research project examines what traditional knowledge and practices of farmers are being revived and retained and/or abandoned by digital farming technologies and what the effects are on farmers’ farming practices and income. To answer these questions, the researcher conducts archival research, analyzes digital datasets, and interviews, participates in and observes the work of farmers who are engaging in the digital farming projects and farmers who are not scientists, engineers and public officials. This research enhances scientific understanding of how emergent technologies and longstanding know-how interact in the production of food, contributing to ethnographic work on the technopolitics of food systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In Turkey, farming and farms are conceptualized as fragile "open factories" that are exposed to ecological, sociopolitical, and financial risks and challenges. In this research, I examine digital farming technologies (e.g. smartphones, drones, auto-steering, GIS, Big Data) as sociotechnical infrastructures intended to address these challanges, while pushing farmers toward greater efficiency for larger yields and better incomes (a widely-accepted goal of agricultural innovation worldwide). This research investigated how such technopolitical interventions seeking food sustainability by increasing efficiency (more yield per unit) produce unanticipated and unacknowledged new forms of agricultural governance, while transforming farmers’ practices, worlviews, and livelihoods. I employed ethnographic research methods to collect data on these issues, including participant observations, interviews, and archival research. I conducted this research with farmers, public officials, agricultural engineers, data scientists, UX/UI designers, software developers, and managers in fields, villages, offices, a smart village project, and technology companies in Turkey.

As a result of the analysis of the collected data, it is evident that farmers are willing to embrace these technologies to address their socioeconomic and ecological challenges. However, some farmers also harbor distrust towards these technologies. Moreover, not all farmers have the necessary resources to benefit from them, hindering their participation in the development processes based on digital farming technologies. In this regard, this study shows the importance of addressing exclusionary aspects of globally emerging digital farming technologies.

Furthermore, this research highlights both ongoing transformations in farmers' practices and the revaluation of some established farming practices, which is facilitated by the use of these technologies. For instance, farmers are being encouraged to adopt new farming practices aimed at sequestering carbon in the soil through instruments using algorithmic calculations. These new practices are reshaping longstanding farming methods, such as plowing and fertilizing. While these innovations introduce additional responsibilities and concerns, in cases where digital farming technologies are incompatible with farmers' existing infrastructures, they lead to a renewed appreciation of longstanding “traditional” farming methods, some of which have been largely forgotten, like rain harvesting. Therefore, my research highlights that while digitalization is often seen as a forward-looking development, in agriculture, it is taking shape through connections with the past. However, it is important to note that this is experienced unevenly by farmers, and not all farmers and practices are equally valued.

This research will serve as the foundation for my doctoral dissertation. I have already submitted an article for publication, which delves into the evolving perspectives and practices of farmers. Additionally, I have prepared a short piece for publication that explores the visions of agricultural companies regarding the automation of farm work. In the coming future, I plan to share the findings with the community members and submit further articles based on this research to peer-reviewed scholarly journals, and eventually complete a book on the subject.
